title: A Springfield man was sentenced for murdering his wife. It wasn’t the first time.
author: Abby Patkin
bullets: Crime Four decades after he was convicted of murdering his wife, Kenneth Robson pleaded guilty to killing another spouse.

By Abby Patkin September 30, 2025 | 3:52 PM 1 minute to read A Springfield man has been sentenced to 25 years to life in prison for killing his wife, a slaying that came 40 years after he was convicted of murdering a previous spouse.
Kenneth Robson, 68, recently pleaded guilty to second-degree murder in the death of 45-year-old Quitiza Holmes, the Hampden County District Attorney’s Office said.

bullets: Readers Say "It’s a beautiful town on the harbor.

title: Report: Rising costs threaten Massachusetts’ competitive edge
author: Beth Treffeisen
bullets: Local News While the state remains strong in talent and quality of life, escalating costs in key sectors, slow transportation times, and stagnant job creation threaten its economy, a new report found.
A view of the Boston skyline.

title: Harvard Square tunnel could be a music venue in the next decade
author: Madison Lucchesi
bullets: Local News The Cambridge City Council outlined steps Monday to potentially transform the tunnel into an underground venue.
Rendering of a potential live event venue in an abandoned MBTA tunnel under Harvard Square, as imagined by the Harvard Square Business Association.

title: Tell us: What’s your message to the Yankees?
author: Annie Jonas
bullets: Tell Us Whether it’s playful banter, clever wordplay, or just some good old-fashioned Boston witticisms, we want to hear from you.
Alex Rodriguez of the New York Yankees heads into first base as Boston Red Sox pitcher Bronson Arroyo tries to tag him, during the eighth inning of Game 6 of the 2004 ALCS.
(Barry Chin/Globe Staff) By Annie Jonas September 30, 2025 | 3:24 PM 1 minute to read One of baseball’s fiercest rivalries is about to take center stage once again.

title: Girl, 13, arrested after apparent online threat to Mass. school
author: Madison Lucchesi
bullets: Crime "Within minutes of receiving notification, via the communication channels that the FBI has developed, the individual who made the post was identified, located, and taken into police custody by the Clinton Police Department.
" A 13-year-old student was arrested for allegedly making a threat to a Clinton school in a social media post.
The female student, whose name was not released due to her juvenile status, was arrested on Monday, according to Clinton Public Schools.

title: Mass. hospital employee fired for not getting COVID vaccine wins her appeal
author: Abby Patkin
bullets: Local News Rachelle Jeune requested a religious exemption after she said she received a “distinctive message from my God” telling her not to get the COVID-19 vaccine.

AP By Abby Patkin September 30, 2025 | 2:50 PM 3 minutes to read A UMass Memorial Health surgical tech fired after she said she “prayed to God and received a message” telling her to refuse the COVID-19 vaccine has won an appeal to continue her religious discrimination lawsuit against the health care organization.
The Appeals Court sided with Rachelle Jeune, who was denied a religious exemption from UMass Memorial Health’s COVID vaccine mandate while working at HealthAlliance-Clinton Hospital in 2021.

title: Former U.S. Attorney Rachael Rollins agrees to public reprimand from Mass. bar

title: Cat Stevens postpones North American tour and cites visa issues
author: The Associated Press
bullets: Concerts Stevens, who was previously scheduled to perform in Boston next week, is the latest in a string of international musicians and athletes impacted by visa issues.
Yusuf Islam, also known as Cat Stevens, performs during Glastonbury Festival in Somerset, England, on June 25, 2023.
Joel C Ryan/Invision/AP, File Cat Stevens, who also goes by Yusuf, has postponed the North American leg of his book tour due to unspecified visa issues, the singer announced on social media Monday.

title: Another Mass. college has Harvard and MIT beat in WSJ’s new ranking
author: Madison Lucchesi
bullets: Education With emphasis on financial preparation, Babson College ranked first in the state and second in the country.
Babson College campus.

Lane Turner/The Boston Globe While Harvard and MIT are no stranger to the tops of college ranking lists, another Massachusetts college ranked first in the state on The Wall Street Journal’s new list of best colleges in America.
